fields.description:
For any Stash repository configured, Bamboo should automatically update Stash with the build status.

* Add an advanced repository option to disable updating Stash
* System property to globally turn off updating build status

This notification type will be removed in 5.7
fields.summary: Stash build status notification moved to Stash connector

fields.description:
This was originally brought up in BAM-14353 and was closed as being a duplicate of BAM-11409. With the resolution and release of BAM-11409, the issue from BAM-14353 is still present. 

The new integrated Stash repository type does not handle notifications to multiple Stash instances (or any instance besides the default instance). No new notification type seems to have been introduced, and adding the existing Stash notification type still does not notify the desired Stash instance. 

This breaks gating of pull requests based on successful builds on secondary Stash instances along with any other Stash functionality dependent on the build notification from Bamboo.

Original description:
{quote}
While application links can be established between Bamboo and multiple Stash instances, notifications are only sent to a single default instance.

If multiple instances are linked, either all instances should be notified by Stash notifications, or a way to specify which instance should be notified should be available when configuring the notification.
{quote}
fields.summary: Notifications for multiple Stash instances

fields.description:
After the last update some of our builds were failing due to a MSBuild error ({{MSBUILD : error MSB1001: Unknown switch.}}), this apparently happens because an option that uses double quotes on its value is treated as if it doesn't have them.

As an example, we use something like {color:blue}{{/p:OctoPackNuGetArguments="-NoDefaultExcludes -Exclude **\*.coffee"}}{color} but it gets executed as if didn't have double quotes and MSBuild throws an error indicating -Exclude is an unknown switch. It's not something specific to this option since the only thing that have changed is our Bamboo version.

One interesting thing to note is that in previous log texts the command was represented without quotes and on the new logs it appears with the quotes (but it doesn't work).
fields.summary: MSBuild options not working properly with double quote enclosed values
Bamboo variables - add variable for last successfully built revision

fields.description:
For example using admin accounts (different names), on both Bamboo and Stash. 

I make sure i am logged off of both..
1. login to bamboo as a local admin account
2. login to stash in another tab as a local admin account
3. Starting from no existing applink on either side
4. Go into Bamboo, and create an applink back to stash 
url: https://scm.principal.com
userbase: different (unchecked)
admin on both: checked
5. It goes through its redirect and then says successfully created applink {}. 
6. I click edit the app link in Bamboo for Stash, and then to Outgoing Auth.
7. Scroll down, and click Enable (under the Trusted App Tab)
8. I click on the incoming auth, and the trusted App Tab), and scroll down and click 'enable'
9. I go to the Stash browser tab, and confirm that the incoming/outgoing auth under Trusted App and OAuth are indeed enabled/configured.
2-leg auth is enabled on both sides (default apparently).

10. I then logout of both Stash and Bamboo..

11. When i login to either ONE product under my own id (that happens to be admin as well).. The applink from the Stash side will be:

Stash Side:
-Outgoing Auth:
+trusted app: asking for creds
+oAuth: asking for creds
+Basic: asking for creds
-incoming auth:
+trusted app: configured
+oAuth: configured
+Basic: asking for creds

12. HOWEVER, if i then login to BOTH applications, then the applink appears configured on both sides under Out/In and Trust App/OAuth

Bamboo side:
-Outgoing Auth:
+trusted app: configured
+oAuth: configured
+Basic: asking for creds/not configured
-incoming auth:
+trusted app: configured
+oAuth: configured
+Basic: asking for creds

13. I am NOT configuring the Basic Access on either side, should i be?
fields.summary: AppLink connections are expiring from Bamboo to any other Application

fields.description:
Deployment project's versioning not showing the correct value or inconsistent. Versioning format:
{noformat}
${bamboo.version}.${bamboo.buildNumber}
{noformat}

_Version_ is a custom variable added in plan config and _buildNumber_ is system variable.

Check the following screenshots for the behavior.
Versioning preview for the current/latest build. The same behavior on clicking *Create Release* from any possible build:
!deploy_current_build.png|thumbnail!

Versioning preview when selecting other build from the list. The preview won't change anymore:
!deploy_previous_build.png|thumbnail!


Final results are affected as well. The versions are inconsistent. The variable *bamboo.version* will increment correctly if nothing touched during the release. If the preview has been changed as in the second screenshot, *bamboo.version* won't have an increment. Following release with untouched versioning will suddenly jump to a number where *bamboo.version* should have been incremented.

!release_versions.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Deployment project's versioning is showing and creating inconsistent results

fields.description:
*Problem Description*
Before Bamboo 5.5, if you specify the Repository URL in the plan variable, and put that variable in the repository URL in the repository setting, it will be replaced just fine. However in Bamboo 5.5, you the variable won't be replaced. It will fail with this error (If you are using Subversion repository).
{noformat}
This is not a valid Subversion repository: svn: E125002: Malformed URL '${bamboo.myVariable}'
{noformat}

This issue won't happen in *Global Variable*.

*Steps to replicate*
# Configure a plan variable in a plan configuration by going to _Variables_ tab.
# Let's make this variable called _myVariable_ and put repository URL in there.
# Configure the repository's URL in _Repositories_ tab and put the following variable in Repository URL.
{noformat}
${bamboo.myVariable}
{noformat}
# Configure the rest of the repository setting and save it.
# Notice that it will fail with error mentioned which caused by the variable is not substituted.

*Workaround*
Use a global variable instead of plan level variable.
fields.summary: Unable to replace plan in the plan repository setting

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce: 
1. Manually create plan branches and bamboo will automatically assign a Plan Key to them. eg: FOO-0, FOO-1, FOO-3.

2. Create multiple deployment versions of FOO-1. Say the last one wast #40, which is release FOO-1-40.
2. Delete FOO-1 plan branch.
3. Keep FOO-2 and FOO-3
4. Create a new branch plan.
5. Sometimes Bamboo will reuse and assign the FOO-1 plan key to the newly create branch. that is when I have problems.

6. Try to create a release from the FOO-1, say release FOO-1-${buildNumber}, which translates to FOO-1-1.

Bamboo will complain that FOO-1-1 cannot be create because it is lower than FOO-1-40 (from step #2 above).

Also, in the create release page, when I select the branch behind the FOO-1 plan key, it will list the build results  created by the branch that was previously pointing to FOO-1. 
That is how I came to realise bamboo was reusing old plan keys from deleted branches.

I hope my explanation isn't too confusing.
fields.summary: Bamboo should not reuse Plan Keys from deleted branches

fields.description:
According to [our Documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Disabling+SSH+access+to+elastic+instances] it's possible to disable the Global SSH access rule from the {{elasticbamboo}} EC2 security group. 

However in Bamboo 5.5-OD-02 Bamboo will automatically put the rule for Global access back into the EC2 security group every time an instance is started. This happens both if the SSH rule is removed entirely, or restricted to a few IPs.
This does not happen in 5.5-OD-01.
fields.summary: Starting an EC2 instance puts Global SSH access rule into the EC2 security group

fields.description:
I'm evaluating Bamboo 5.5.0 and tried importing jobs from our existing Jenkins install (1.554.1 LTS).  Problem is, every job uses Perforce and the importer sees this as a fatal condition.

Per a twitter conversation with James Dumay, he thought the importer would just not bring in the SCM config but otherwise bring in other parts of the job.  My import experience did not match this.

I'd like to see the importer enhanced to support bringing in jobs and leaving the SCM configuration out, vs the current situation where nothing comes across.  This would still save time, as the end user could then go job by job and fix the SCM configuration.

Relevant text from an import log:

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Job name: AndroidClient-Trunk-Continuous
SEVERITY: HIGH
Unsupported configuration for plugin 'hudson.plugins.buildblocker.BuildBlockerProperty'
SEVERITY: HIGH
Unsupported configuration for plugin 'hudson.plugins.disk_usage.DiskUsageProperty'
SEVERITY: HIGH
Unsupported configuration for plugin 'hudson.plugins.perforce.PerforceSCM'
SEVERITY: HIGH
Unsupported configuration for plugin 'hudson.plugins.warnings.WarningsPublisher'
SEVERITY: HIGH
Unsupported configuration for plugin 'hudson.plugins.tasks.TasksPublisher'
SEVERITY: HIGH
Unsupported configuration for plugin 'hudson.plugins.violations.ViolationsPublisher'
SEVERITY: HIGH
Unsupported configuration for plugin 'Email-ext'
SEVERITY: FATAL
Scm cannot be imported
fields.summary: Jenkins importer should not fatal when unsupported SCMs are detected.

fields.description:
The zip download of Bamboo is bundled with the 32 bits tomcat which works fine for both 32 or 64 bits JVM. Now the issue is when we try to install as a service on windows 64 bits. The service installation will fail because the tomcat binaries are 32 bits. We have this issue documented in the [JIRA knowledge base article|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/Problems+Installing+JIRA+applications+as+a+service+on+Windows+64bit] which involves replacing the binaries.

It will be nice if we just provide different downloads for 32 and 64bits.
fields.summary: Distribute Bamboo zip downloads for 32 and 64 bits

fields.description:
Currently we have over a 300 plans. When we create a branch we like the branch feature, however we can't use it, because sooner or later someone is going to change something in the definition of the plan in trunk (add a new stage job, change some parameters etc..), which will then break the builds in the branches.

So we are now back to copying the plan for every branch, which quickly leads to a huge number of plans.

It would be nice if bamboo cloned the definition of the plan on branch creation, so that if something changes either in the branch or in trunk (or another branch) it doesn't break the definition in all other branches/trunk
fields.summary: Plan definition per branch.

simple	07-May-2014 04:47:52	
simple	07-May-2014 04:47:52	If you want to create a new branch to retain commits you create, you may
simple	07-May-2014 04:47:52	do so (now or later) by using -b with the checkout command again. Example:
simple	07-May-2014 04:47:52	
simple	07-May-2014 04:47:52	  git checkout -b new_branch_name
simple	07-May-2014 04:47:52	
simple	07-May-2014 04:47:52	HEAD is now at 68476d6... Merge branch 'master' of ssh://stash.atlassian.com:7997/jag/jira-agile
simple	07-May-2014 04:47:52	Checkout completed, recover successful.
simple	07-May-2014 04:47:52	Updated source code to revision: 68476d668e8ec9af983a4e02835c1cdb99f97db3
simple	07-May-2014 04:47:52	Finished task 'Checkout Repository greenhopper'
{noformat}

Normally this is not a big problem. But when trying to do a release with Maven, one of the actions is to commit the usual Maven version bump and push the commits back upstream. But in a 'detached HEAD' situation, there is no branch to commit back. Hence the release fails:
{noformat}
build	07-May-2014 04:59:37	[INFO] Executing: /bin/sh -c cd /opt/bamboo-agent/xml-data/build-dir/GH-DEVPIPELINE-RELEASE/artifact && git commit --verbose -F /tmp/maven-scm-129526871.commit pom.xml greenhopper-api/pom.xml greenhopper-jira-bridge-parent/pom.xml greenhopper-jira-bridge-parent/greenhopper-jira-bridge/pom.xml greenhopper-jira-bridge-parent/greenhopper-jira60-bridge/pom.xml greenhopper-jira-bridge-parent/greenhopper-jira61-bridge/pom.xml greenhopper-jira-bridge-parent/greenhopper-jira611-bridge/pom.xml greenhopper-jira-bridge-parent/greenhopper-jira62-bridge/pom.xml greenhopper/pom.xml greenhopper-client/pom.xml greenhopper-integration-test/pom.xml ondemand-acceptance-tests/pom.xml greenhopper-tpm-test/pom.xml greenhopper-tpm-test/spm/pom.xml greenhopper-performance-test/pom.xml
build	07-May-2014 04:59:37	[INFO] Working directory: /opt/bamboo-agent/xml-data/build-dir/GH-DEVPIPELINE-RELEASE/artifact
build	07-May-2014 04:59:37	[INFO] Executing: /bin/sh -c cd /opt/bamboo-agent/xml-data/build-dir/GH-DEVPIPELINE-RELEASE/artifact && git symbolic-ref HEAD
build	07-May-2014 04:59:37	[INFO] Working directory: /opt/bamboo-agent/xml-data/build-dir/GH-DEVPIPELINE-RELEASE/artifact
build	07-May-2014 04:59:37	[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
build	07-May-2014 04:59:37	[ERROR] BUILD ERROR
build	07-May-2014 04:59:37	[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
build	07-May-2014 04:59:37	[INFO] An error is occurred in the checkin process: Exception while executing SCM command.
build	07-May-2014 04:59:37	
build	07-May-2014 04:59:37	Detecting the current branch failed: fatal: ref HEAD is not a symbolic ref
{noformat}

I failed to reproduce this issue by triggering a retry with a dummy repository sourced on Bitbucket. But still I consider this a bug - the checkout of a given branch should never leave me in a detached state. I'm aware that there are issues when the branch has 'moved on' and the commit hash used to check out no longer references the HEAD.

In this case the clone was done using the HTTPS protocol with the _Use shallow clones_ options set. Would it make a difference to
# Uncheck the _Use shallow clones_ option
# Checkout by using the ssh protocol

?
fields.summary: Retried checkout of a git repository can leave it in a detached HEAD state causing Maven releases to fail

fields.description:
In Junit, failed tests have a failure tag that is read by Bamboo and displayed in the test summary as reason for failed test. See the attached screenshot:
!Capture.PNG|thumbnail!

There are instances where successful tests can have tags like the system-out. It will be nice to capture that as well and show in the summary. Here is an example
{code}
 <testcase classname="SultanTest" name="test" time="0.0">
    <system-out message="some test descriptions." type="" />
  </testcase>
{code}
fields.summary: successful Junit test that have details should be captured in the test summary

fields.description:

fields.description:
If I hae a plan with 2 repos and provide a custom commit for the default repo, the build actually reports that the customised version was the commit the second repo used, not the one I provided.

You can see in the attachment that the title bar has the correct revision, but under that it says I overrode the second repos version, which I did not.
fields.summary: Build reports wrong repo/commit as being overridden

See screenshot.
The last word of the grey-colored description is re*s*pository.
fields.summary: Typo on "Shared credentials" administration page

fields.description:
BAMBOO does not associate commits to builds anywhere except the HEAD. 

This is unacceptable. 

There may be many commits on a branch between builds. Especially if the builds are manual. Or build plans are 'paused' or being changed.

Bamboo MUST query all commits performed between builds (not just the HEAD) and associate Jira issues to the first build that is relevant to the the issue.
fields.summary: Bamboo needs to expend criteria for "Build->Issue" association

fields.description: I'd like to be able to quickly look at the status of all of the plans that contain a branch. It is easy to see the status of the master branch on the allPlans page or the Wallboard, but I'd like to see the status of each of those plans on branch LABEL-123 for example. Adding this as a filter option to the allPlans and Wallboard would be great.
fields.summary: View build status of all plans containing branch

fields.description: I want to be able to manually trigger to run all plans that have a particular branch. A number of my plans take on the order of 30 minutes to finish, so they are normally scheduled to run at midnight. I'd like the ability to manually run all of them in one operation/button click without having to click into each plan and run them all individually.
fields.summary: Manual run all plans that contain branch

fields.description:
Bamboo grabs git author information from the committer info and not the author info.

Stash, on the other hand, grabs the author information from the author ID and shows up as expected.

Please make bamboo grab git author information from the author information and not the committer info.
fields.summary: Bamboo grabs git author information from the committer info and not the author info.

fields.description:
Duke Nguyen said:

The "Artifact Download" task in a deployment project allows you to select "All artifacts" or "Individual Artifacts".

However, when I click "Add another artifact", it only lets you choose "All artifacts", as opposed to letting you choose individual artifacts. Creating a brand new "Artifact Download" task allows you to select All or Individual though, but never via "Add another artifact".

This is a regression, because this used to work a month or so ago.

https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/291074/bamboo-ondemand-artifact-download-selection
fields.summary: Artifact Downloader "Add another artifact" doesn't work correctly (regression)

fields.description:
{panel:title=Workaround}
To work around this issue, you can just re-enable the plugin
# Go to Administration -> Manage add-ons
# Select "System" from the filter drop down
# Find the plugin "System Builders"
# Enable it!
{panel}

fields.description:
As described in this below Answers request...

https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/82988/branch-merging-with-gatekeeper-and-push-on-causes-git-failures-with-concurrent-builds

We are having the scenario where our build is long enough and we have enough teammates working on the same repo that branch merges being done by the gatekeeper process fail for not being at tip.

We have restricted the build to a single remote agent as a workaround.  I would like to know if there is a configuration setting to toggle this behavior though.

I've checked the docs (https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/job), and I understand what a job is relative to a plan and a stage and a project - a very nice hierarchy. But apart from being defined relative to one another, it's not at all clear what a "Job" (or any of the others) are.

fields.description:
h1. Overview

The ability to flexibly manage / register Deployment environments, where these environments are created/instanced in 'the cloud' and exist as part of an elastic infrastructure.

h1. Background

Having switched from SVN to Mercurial/Git we have found that using Branches to develop and test on has become a best-practice in our teams. One impact of this change, however, is that we now find that we are restricted on the number of physical test environments in which we can deploy to.

As a result, we've begun investigating using AWS in a way similar to the 'elastic agent' concept by which we create a 'snapshot' test environment build, and then create test environment instances from that snapshot which are then deployed to as though any other test environment.

h1. Implementation Thoughts

I could see this being done in one of two ways:
# Follow a similar approach to Elastic Build Agents where users...
## Create and register AMI's with Bamboo
## When a new Environment is required, Bamboo can manage the initialisation of an instance based on that environment
## When the Environment is no-longer required, Bamboo can manage the shut-down/hibernation/termination of that environment
## Value-Add features under this approach would be to have the ability to snapshot the Instance at given points in time so that 'child'/'related' instances can be created at any point to allow Developers and QA teams to work in tandem without necessary disrupting one-another
# Provide API Access to the Deployment administrative functions which can be used by an Instance-triggered script to...
## Create an Environment definition in Bamboo on Boot
## Remove the Environment definition from Bamboo on Termination/Shut-Down
fields.summary: Elastic Environments to support Branch Development

fields.description:
Hi Atlassian :-)

Today we have to create artifact for each directory in a tree if we want exclude many directories. The lacks of possibilities in configuration with the ant patterns force to create too many artifacts and thus the use of bamboo for deployment is lesser interesting whereas the possibilities of rollback deployment within artifact are very useful. 

At least, i would like a functionnality to exclude/include files when i create an artifact. With this possibility, Bamboo would be very powerful for us !!!

thanks by advance

ps : maybe it's available in last version 5.4 or maybe i don't know all the possibilities in writing ant pattern on a simple line.
fields.summary: Exclude files from artifacts

fields.description:
We have fixed a vulnerability in our version of Apache Struts. Attackers can use this vulnerability to execute Java code of their choice on systems that use these frameworks. The attacker needs to be able to access the Bamboo web interface. In cases when anonymous access is enabled, a valid user account is not required to exploit this vulnerability.

We have discovered this vulnerability during our review of the recent Struts security advisories. This vulnerability is specific to Bamboo.
The vulnerability affects all versions of Bamboo up to and including 5.5. 

For more information see the full [advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+Security+Advisory+2014-05-21].
fields.summary: ClassLoader Manipulation vulnerability

fields.description:
Environment: Windows 7 32bit in a VM

Repro Steps:
1. Create plan (Create->Create a new plan), enter plan details
2. Enter following information in the 'Source Repositories' section:
  * Source Repository: Bitbucket
  * Display name: My Repository
  * Username: atlassian_dragons
  * Password: <leave blank>
3. Click "Load Repositories"
  * Confirm that default repository url appears (...atlassian_dragons/dragonslayers)
4. Leave the rest of fields in their default values
5. Click "Configure Plan"
6. Click "Add Task" and add a Maven build step
7. Save Maven build step and check Enable plan
8. Click "Create"

Expected Results: Build to run successfully
Actual Results: The build produces an error "Unable to detect changes" (error details added as an attachment BambooException.rtf)

Workaround: To work around this problem in Step 2 a fake Password can be supplied e.g. "fakepass"

fields.description:
From: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-13705
{quote}
Some background... We run the standalone configuration, but have an F5 in front of it acting as a proxy, handling SSL traffic and redirecting non-SSL traffic to https:// based URLs. However, from the standalone tomcat's viewpoint, it thinks it is running under normal http://
When I was having these problems, I would only see a log line like this (not the exact log line, but similar), and noticed it was making a restful type request from the javascript in the page to a http:// based URL

{code}2014-04-30 09:32:34,866 INFO [http-bio-8080-exec-17] [AccessLogFilter] XXX PUT http://XXXXXX/rest/applinks/2.0/applicationlink 66004kb{code}
In our setup, that would have been redirected to the https://bamboo... version of the URL, and I don't believe your javascript is handling that correctly. So I think the fix on your side is one of the following (#2 is easy)
1) Fix the javascript to continue the authentication process through redirects that might happen
2) Use the Base URL server address that I have configured in the General Configuration tab (It is set to https://XXXXXX)
I was able to work around this, by reconfiguring tomcat slightly so that it knew it was behind a proxy and thought it was serving https:. I added the following couple of lines to the Connector configuration in the server.xml file. Once I did that and restarted, I was able to configure the application links successfully.
scheme="https"
proxyPort="443"
{quote}
fields.summary: Applinks through an SSL handling proxy can sometimes cause url rewrite issue

fields.description:
In "Plan Configuration" / "Branches", the checkbox "Branch merging enabled" provides the option to automatically merge changes to/from the branch that is being automatically managed.

We need a filter added within this section so that only branches matching a certain pattern (e.g. starting with "release-") will be automatically merged.

There is already the filter "Only create branches that match ...", but this is used to determine which branches have *builds* - for *merging* we need a second filter.

Currently our filter for automatically managing branches is ".*" (maybe it can be blank?), and a typical list of branches (and their corresponding build plans) might look like:

{quote}master
DEV-1234
DEV-2345
DEV-3456
release-foo
release-bar{quote}

Our workflow is roughly like this:

* Create a release branch from master
* Create an issue branch, PR/merge to the release branch (the approver will do the merge)
* Merge the release branch into master

That last step is manual, and I want it to be automated, without needing to manually edit each branch plan just after Bamboo creates it.

Just to recap, the second filter is needed because I don't want branches such as DEV-1234 automatically merged to master, even after a successful build. It needs to happen when the changes are merged to a release branch, and the release branch successfully builds.
fields.summary: Add optional filter for branch merging

fields.description:
When configuring an OnDemand EC2 image, there are separate drop downs to select "Virtual Private Cloud subnet" and "Availability zone." If no VPC subnet is selected, then we have the option of selecting "Chosen by EC2" as the availability zone.

But if we *do* specify a VPC, well, each VPC subnet is assigned to a particular AZ, so the entire image configuration is pinned to a particular AZ.

We prefer to use multiple VPCs configured in multiple AZs, and we'd like Bamboo to select the cheapest AZ when launching the build.

This matters to us because we use spot pricing to buy our instances; it's not uncommon for prices in just one AZ to spike way up. When that happens, we'd like to start VMs in a cheaper AZ.

Currently we handle this by creating three image configurations for three AZs, but Bamboo doesn't necessarily start the VM in the cheapest zone. According to https://support.atlassian.com/servicedesk/customer/jst/usage-query-91066 "The order is not specified and not guaranteed,it can be either of these images and it can change after JVM upgrade"

That means that Bamboo isn't optimizing our bidding correctly; this bug costs us money.
fields.summary: Allow an EC2 image configuration to have multiple VPC AZs; choose the cheapest

fields.description:
I created a Build Project that involved the use of 5 shared repositories. Then, I cloned this project, and changed the default source repository, to have branches automatically created and built when changes occurred on this second repository. When I manually run a branch (Gatekeeper turned on w/out push), I get a build error, and the log tab has the following:

Checked out: develop 31179.... 
Merged with: feature/feature1 c4c284....
Failure reason: Merge command error: fatal: 'c4c284....' does not point to a commit

The interesting thing is that the develop hash is the same as the develop HEAD for the repository that was the OLD default, evidence of it looking at the wrong source repository. Even if I change the default, the cloned plan doesn't work. However, when I rebuild the plan from scratch, it works as expected.
fields.summary: Cloned Build Plan stuck on default repository

fields.description:
We've multiple project internally at my company, each of which in turn have a number of plans on Bamboo. At busy times, we inevitably run out of agents to meet the demand & a queue builds up. 

This in itself is fine, but what can happen is that if we have 5 agents and Project A has created 10 different plans, they can manage to both occupy every available agent and have the top 5 places in the queue — projects B & C are then stuck behind this, unless they ask an admin to bump them to the top of the queue, or have agents assigned that A cannot use.

Ideally, what we'd like is to have some throttling in place, where if a project A is using more than N agents, any queued builds from projects B and C get promoted to the top of the queue.

Let me know if you need more details on what I mean, (or if I should raise this elsewhere!)

Thanks
Dave
fields.summary: Allowing throttling of build agents on a per project basis

fields.description:
I have a build project 'myproject', and a corresponding deployment project.

The build project defines an artifact 'myartifact', from path 'target' using pattern '*.zip'. We produce a build (let's call this 'build 1'). The deployment project has a task to download all shared artifacts - and when we deploy 'build 1' it gets 'myartifact' and carries on - so far so good. 

Time marches on, and we need to make some adjustments to the structure of 'myproject'. The artifact 'myartifact' is now obtained from 'foo/target', and we adjust the artifact definition accordingly. We produce a build (let's call this 'build 2')

When we try to deploy 'build 2' we get the artifact that we need and the deployment succeeds. If we try to deploy 'build 1', it fails because it can't find an artifact under 'foo/target' - and there was indeed no such artifact, because we had not yet made the structural changes.

This seems completely wrong to me. Existing builds should not be affected by changes to the build plan. Each build should hold its own knowledge about the artifacts that it contains - this should not come from the current build plan. Because of this apparent bug, we can no longer make deployments of 'build 1'. This will quickly become a showstopper for us, unless there is some kind of workaround - and I can't think of any.

*Update:* This does appear to be a bug relating to the 'Artifact Download' task used in the deployment plan. When inspecting the build result using the Bamboo REST API, the artifacts are correctly defined and can be downloaded successfully.
fields.summary: Shared artifacts are tied directly to the current build plan

Ant executable requires a few .jar files in the same folder to run. These jars are located in /usr/share/ant/lib

When click on detect server capabilities on Bamboo, it would automatically set the path of ant to "/usr". This would lead to a build error complaining that some class could not be found in Java.

Work around:

Create a symlink of ant executable in /usr/share/ant/bin/ant -> /usr/bin/ant

Manually set the path of Ant to be "/usr/share/ant"
